_**The Late Show with Stephen Colbert**_ is an American [late-night talk
show](/wiki/Late-night_talk_show "Late-night talk show") hosted by [Stephen
Colbert](/wiki/Stephen_Colbert "Stephen Colbert"), which premiered on
September 8, 2015. Produced by [Spartina
Productions](/wiki/Spartina_Productions "Spartina Productions") and [CBS
Television Studios](/wiki/CBS_Television_Studios "CBS Television Studios"),
_The Late Show_ _with Stephen Colbert_ is the second iteration of CBS's [_Late
Show_ franchise](/wiki/Late_Show_\(CBS_TV_series\) "Late Show \(CBS TV
series\)"). [Stay Human](/wiki/Stay_Human_\(band\) "Stay Human \(band\)"), led
by bandleader [Jon Batiste](/wiki/Jon_Batiste "Jon Batiste"), serves as the
program's [house band](/wiki/House_band "House band"), and the announcer is
program writer Jen Spyra.

The program is taped at the [Ed Sullivan Theater](/wiki/Ed_Sullivan_Theater
"Ed Sullivan Theater") in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City")
and airs live to tape in most U.S. markets at 11:35 p.m. Eastern and Pacific,
and 10:35 in the Central.

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

Prior to Colbert's assumption of hosting duties, [David
Letterman](/wiki/David_Letterman "David Letterman") had been host of _[Late
Show](/wiki/Late_Show_with_David_Letterman "Late Show with David Letterman")_
for 22 years, dating to his arrival at CBS in 1993. CBS had not had a regular
late-night talk show for most of its existence prior to that point, with only
one attempt (the short-lived _[Pat Sajak Show](/wiki/The_Pat_Sajak_Show "The
Pat Sajak Show")_ in 1990) between 1972 and Letterman's arrival. Letterman,
who joined CBS from [NBC](/wiki/NBC "NBC") after ending his eleven-year run as
host of _[Late Night](/wiki/Late_Night_with_David_Letterman "Late Night with
David Letterman")_ and losing out on being [Johnny Carson](/wiki/Johnny_Carson
"Johnny Carson")'s successor on _[The Tonight Show](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show
"The Tonight Show")_ to [Jay Leno](/wiki/Jay_Leno "Jay Leno"), was initially
competitive with his show's bitter rival, _[The Tonight Show with Jay
Leno](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_with_Jay_Leno "The Tonight Show with Jay Leno")_
; Letterman's _Late Show_ , however, slowly experienced a decline in ratings
over the course of the 1990s and 2000s, dating back to an [affiliation
agreement](/wiki/1994_United_States_broadcast_TV_realignment "1994 United
States broadcast TV realignment") between [New World
Communications](/wiki/New_World_Pictures#New_World_Communications "New World
Pictures") and [Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting
Company") that resulted in all nine CBS-affiliated stations it owned or
recently acquired switching to Fox between September and December 1994,
relegating the network to lower-rated former Fox affiliates and [independent
stations](/wiki/Independent_station_\(North_America\) "Independent station
\(North America\)") in many major cities.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Stephen_Colbert_November_2016.jpg/170px-
Stephen_Colbert_November_2016.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stephen_Colbert_November_2016.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Stephen_Colbert_November_2016.jpg "Enlarge")

[Stephen Colbert](/wiki/Stephen_Colbert "Stephen Colbert") hosted his
satirical news show, _[The Colbert Report](/wiki/The_Colbert_Report "The
Colbert Report")_ , which won seven [Primetime Emmy
Awards](/wiki/Primetime_Emmy_Award "Primetime Emmy Award") on [Comedy
Central](/wiki/Comedy_Central "Comedy Central"), from October 2005 to December
2014

According to [TV by the Numbers](/wiki/TV_by_the_Numbers "TV by the Numbers"),
in February 2013, the live-plus-seven-day ratings for Letterman's _Late Show_
averaged about 3.1 million per show for the 2012–13 season to date.[1] A year
later, average viewership was down to 2.8 million.[2] _Late Show_ also had the
oldest audience among the various late-night talk shows, which may have led to
CBS' decision to pick a younger replacement for Letterman to compete with
_[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy
Fallon](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Jimmy_Fallon "The Tonight Show
Starring Jimmy Fallon")_ and [ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company
"American Broadcasting Company")'s _[Jimmy Kimmel
Live!](/wiki/Jimmy_Kimmel_Live! "Jimmy Kimmel Live!")_.[2] In addition,
Colbert's previous program did well among college students and young men
18–34, which are prime target audiences for late-night comedy programming.[2]

On April 3, 2014, Letterman announced his retirement, with his final episode
as host of _Late Show_ scheduled for May 20, 2015. On April 10, 2014, CBS
announced [Stephen Colbert](/wiki/Stephen_Colbert "Stephen Colbert") as
Letterman's successor, signing him to a five-year agreement.[3] In contrast
with Colbert's previous program _[The Colbert Report](/wiki/The_Colbert_Report
"The Colbert Report")_ , in which he played a [fictionalized version of
himself](/wiki/Stephen_Colbert_\(character\) "Stephen Colbert \(character\)"),
Colbert hosts the show (which retains the _Late Show_ branding, albeit with
the article "The" formally inserted into the title) as himself.[4] On April
23, 2014, the character version of Stephen Colbert appeared on _[The Daily
Show with Jon Stewart](/wiki/The_Daily_Show_with_Jon_Stewart "The Daily Show
with Jon Stewart")_ to announce that he had clearly "won television" and would
be closing down _The Colbert Report_ because he had met his goal. This came
after the announcement the character would not be used after the end of _The
Colbert Report_.[5] The final episode of _Report_ aired on December 18, 2014.

Several states and municipalities attempted to coax CBS into moving production
of the program from its long-time home in New York City with tax credits and
other incentives, including Los Angeles, [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New
Orleans") and [Connecticut](/wiki/Connecticut "Connecticut").[6] On July 23,
2014, CBS announced that _Late Show_ would continue to be produced at the [Ed
Sullivan Theater](/wiki/Ed_Sullivan_Theater "Ed Sullivan Theater") in New York
when Colbert takes over.[7] [Jonathan Batiste](/wiki/Jonathan_Batiste
"Jonathan Batiste") was announced as the bandleader on June 4, 2015,[8] with
his [Stay Human](/wiki/Stay_Human_\(band\) "Stay Human \(band\)") band
succeeding the CBS Orchestra (which returned to its previous identity as the
[World's Most Dangerous
Band](/wiki/Paul_Shaffer_and_the_World%27s_Most_Dangerous_Band "Paul Shaffer
and the World's Most Dangerous Band") shortly thereafter) as the [house
band](/wiki/House_band "House band").[9][10]

###
Promotion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Promotion")]

In anticipation of the program's premiere, a new online presence was launched
for _The Late Show_ in June 2015, including new social media accounts, a
[podcast](/wiki/Podcast "Podcast"), mobile app, and a monologue-styled video
focusing on the beard Colbert had grown since leaving _The Colbert
Report_.[11] Throughout the remainder of the summer, videos would continue to
be released through the show's official [YouTube](/wiki/YouTube "YouTube")
channel and mobile app. On July 1, 2015, Colbert hosted a special edition of a
[public access](/wiki/Public_access_television "Public access television")
program in [Monroe, Michigan](/wiki/Monroe,_Michigan "Monroe, Michigan"),
interviewing [Eminem](/wiki/Eminem "Eminem").[12][13]

##
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/LateshowDSC00594.jpg/140px-
LateshowDSC00594.jpg)](/wiki/File:LateshowDSC00594.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:LateshowDSC00594.jpg "Enlarge")

The Ed Sullivan Theater's marquee

Colbert has been given near-full control of the show, with little interference
from CBS management in regard to format.[14][15] Colbert brought most of his
staff from _The Colbert Report_ with him to _The Late Show_ ,[14] as well as
outsiders such as [Brian Stack](/wiki/Brian_Stack "Brian Stack"), who is best
known for his work on [Conan O'Brien](/wiki/Conan_O%27Brien "Conan O'Brien")'s
programs,[16] and [Jon Stewart](/wiki/Jon_Stewart "Jon Stewart"), former host
of Colbert's previous sister program _[The Daily Show](/wiki/The_Daily_Show
"The Daily Show")_ , who is credited as executive producer.[17] Colbert no
longer uses the [character](/wiki/Stephen_Colbert_\(character\) "Stephen
Colbert \(character\)") he had portrayed on _The Colbert Report_ , jokingly
remarking to [Jeb Bush](/wiki/Jeb_Bush "Jeb Bush") that "I used to play a
narcissistic conservative pundit – now I'm just a narcissist."[17]

The Ed Sullivan Theater underwent a full restoration to its original 1927
splendor in a process that began following Letterman's final episode,
including the uncovering of the theater's ceiling, stained-glass windows and a
restoration of a chandelier, due to advances in technology that allow less
sound and video equipment to cover up the auditorium's architectural details.
The 1993 restoration project for Letterman was only done on a few months'
notice after the theater was repurchased in February 1993 by CBS.[18]

In April 2016, former _[CBS This Morning](/wiki/CBS_This_Morning "CBS This
Morning")_ executive producer [Chris Licht](/wiki/Chris_Licht "Chris Licht")
was named [showrunner](/wiki/Showrunner "Showrunner") for _The Late Show_ ;
CBS had shown concerns that, despite improved ratings in comparison to
Letterman's tenure, Colbert had a weak online presence in comparison to _[The
Tonight Show Starring Jimmy
Fallon](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Jimmy_Fallon "The Tonight Show
Starring Jimmy Fallon")_ , and Colbert's lead-out _[The Late Late Show with
James Corden](/wiki/The_Late_Late_Show_with_James_Corden "The Late Late Show
with James Corden")_ (whose "Carpool Karaoke" segments have been popular as
[viral videos](/wiki/Viral_video "Viral video")). _The Hollywood Reporter_
believed that Licht's experience in news programming would be leveraged to
complement Colbert's strengths in topical and news-oriented material.[19]

##
Format[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Format")]

See also: [List of The Late Show with Stephen Colbert
sketches](/wiki/List_of_The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert_sketches "List of
The Late Show with Stephen Colbert sketches")

Colbert originally started the show with a [cold open](/wiki/Cold_open "Cold
open") and brief monologue before the opening sequence, which uses [tilt–shift
photography](/wiki/Tilt%E2%80%93shift_photography "Tilt–shift photography") of
day and night [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City "New York City") scenes that
make the city appear like a miniature model. During the opening sequence, a
[voice-over](/wiki/Voice-over "Voice-over") announces the night's guests.[20]
Starting with the April 18, 2016 broadcast, the first under new showrunner
Chris Licht, the format was modified to replace the cold open monologue with
short sketches starring Colbert, his staff, and often featuring that night's
guests, followed by the opening sequence and Colbert entering the stage.[21]
Starting with the coverage of the Republican National Convention in July 2016,
a new opening has debuted which starts off with writer Jen Spyra taking on the
role of announcer—becoming the first female announcer in broadcast, late-night
television—and announcing "It's The Late Show With Stephen Colbert!" to scenes
of New York City at night including [Yankee Stadium](/wiki/Yankee_Stadium
"Yankee Stadium"), [Times Square](/wiki/Times_Square "Times Square") and the
[New York City Subway](/wiki/New_York_City_Subway "New York City Subway"),
with names of the night's guests imposed on various places. This structure is
similar to the openings of other late-night shows such as _[The Tonight
Show](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Jimmy_Fallon "The Tonight Show Starring
Jimmy Fallon")_ or _[Late Night](/wiki/Late_Night_with_Seth_Meyers "Late Night
with Seth Meyers")_. Similar to _The Colbert Report_ , graphics that resemble
the American Flag have also been added.

The open is followed by an extended [fake news](/wiki/News_satire "News
satire") style desk sequence with a run-through of recent headlines, in a
manner reminiscent of television newscasts and that of _[The Colbert
Report](/wiki/The_Colbert_Report "The Colbert Report")_.[22] Also, the show
follows the same basic format as other late-night talk shows including the use
of [sketch comedy](/wiki/Sketch_comedy "Sketch comedy"), guest interviews and
musical performances. Colbert's guest list includes more political and
government figures than his contemporaries; his first two weeks' guests
included visits from [Jeb Bush](/wiki/Jeb_Bush "Jeb Bush"), [Joe
Biden](/wiki/Joe_Biden "Joe Biden"), [Ban Ki-moon](/wiki/Ban_Ki-moon "Ban Ki-
moon"), [Stephen Breyer](/wiki/Stephen_Breyer "Stephen Breyer"), [Bernie
Sanders](/wiki/Bernie_Sanders "Bernie Sanders"), [Elizabeth
Warren](/wiki/Elizabeth_Warren "Elizabeth Warren"), [Donald
Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump"), and [Ted Cruz](/wiki/Ted_Cruz "Ted
Cruz").

Thus far, Colbert has not had any of his staff act as a
[sidekick](/wiki/Sidekick "Sidekick") or [straight
man](/wiki/Straight_man_\(stock_character\) "Straight man \(stock
character\)") on the show. While Colbert dances and physically interacts with
Jon Batiste while the band plays, they only occasionally engage in on-air
banter, unlike David Letterman's relationship with [Paul
Shaffer](/wiki/Paul_Shaffer "Paul Shaffer") or the relationship of other late
night hosts with their announcers or bandleaders. After the first few episodes
in which Colbert introduced himself, he now uses an off-screen announcer.
Occasionally, Colbert has brought out producers of his show, or enlisted the
help of audience members, who assume a sidekick-like role for single segments,
engaging in light dialogue about a topic.

### Notable
episodes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Notable episodes")]

In the show's series premiere, Colbert welcomed actor [George
Clooney](/wiki/George_Clooney "George Clooney") and politician [Jeb
Bush](/wiki/Jeb_Bush "Jeb Bush"), thanked former host David Letterman, and
joined singer [Mavis Staples](/wiki/Mavis_Staples "Mavis Staples") and
numerous other musicians for a rendition of [Sly and the Family
Stone](/wiki/Sly_and_the_Family_Stone "Sly and the Family Stone")'s "[Everyday
People](/wiki/Everyday_People "Everyday People")."[23] The episode nearly
missed its broadcast due to technical difficulties.[24] An early interview
with Vice President [Joe Biden](/wiki/Joe_Biden "Joe Biden") received
particular acclaim.[25][26][27]

Following the [terrorist attacks in Paris](/wiki/November_2015_Paris_attacks
"November 2015 Paris attacks") that November, Colbert devoted his program to
that city.[28] A special football-themed episode aired as the [lead-out
program](/wiki/List_of_Super_Bowl_lead-out_programs "List of Super Bowl lead-
out programs") for [Super Bowl 50](/wiki/Super_Bowl_50 "Super Bowl 50") in
2016, featuring guests President [Barack Obama](/wiki/Barack_Obama "Barack
Obama") (in a taped segment), [Tina Fey](/wiki/Tina_Fey "Tina Fey"), [Margot
Robbie](/wiki/Margot_Robbie "Margot Robbie"), [Will
Ferrell](/wiki/Will_Ferrell "Will Ferrell"), and [Megyn
Kelly](/wiki/Megyn_Kelly "Megyn Kelly").[29]

On June 22, 2016, CBS announced that _The Late Show_ would broadcast two weeks
of live episodes during the 2016
[Republican](/wiki/2016_Republican_National_Convention "2016 Republican
National Convention") and
[Democratic](/wiki/2016_Democratic_National_Convention "2016 Democratic
National Convention") conventions. The first of these episodes, on July 18,
2016, opened with a musical number by Colbert that compared the Republican
convention to being "[Christmas in July](/wiki/Christmas_in_July "Christmas in
July")", and featured sketches where [Jon Stewart](/wiki/Jon_Stewart "Jon
Stewart") (revealed to have been living off-grid in a cabin) is told that
[Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") had clinched the Republican
nomination for the [presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016 "United States
presidential election, 2016"), Colbert's
[persona](/wiki/Stephen_Colbert_\(character\) "Stephen Colbert \(character\)")
from _The Colbert Report_ is revived and delivers an edition of [The
Word](/wiki/Recurring_segments_on_The_Colbert_Report#The_Word "Recurring
segments on The Colbert Report") on "[Trumpiness](/wiki/Trumpiness
"Trumpiness")", and a filmed sketch touring the convention's
[venue](/wiki/Quicken_Loans_Arena "Quicken Loans Arena") as his _[The Hunger
Games](/wiki/The_Hunger_Games "The Hunger Games")_ -inspired character Julius
Flickerman.[30][31][32] Stewart appeared once more the following Thursday,
delivering a segment criticizing the [Fox News Channel](/wiki/Fox_News_Channel
"Fox News Channel") in the wake of the firing of its CEO [Roger
Ailes](/wiki/Roger_Ailes "Roger Ailes"). Colbert's performances during these
episodes were critically praised for their return to an emphasis on news-
oriented comedy similar to _The Colbert Report_ and _The Daily Show_.[33][34]

On May 1, 2017, in recognition of the completion of the first 100 days of
President Donald Trump's administration, Stephen Colbert's monologue was
devoted to the president. After showing the interview from the previous day in
which President Trump participated in an interview with CBS's [John
Dickerson](/wiki/John_Dickerson_\(journalist\) "John Dickerson
\(journalist\)") on _Face the Nation_ and referred to the show as "Deface the
Nation" and abruptly ending the interview without answering one of Dickerson's
questions, Colbert began his monologue,[35] where “The only thing your mouth
is good for is being Vladimir Putin’s cock holster," was one of a barrage of
pointed missives toward Trump in the 12-minute-long monologue. Colbert later
addressed the controversy on-air, expressing surprise that he was not fired
for the remark, admitting he had used language that was too strong, but also
stating that he was generally unrepentant over the rant and that "I have
jokes; he has the launch codes. So, it’s a fair fight."[36] On May 5, the
[FCC](/wiki/Federal_Communications_Commission "Federal Communications
Commission") announced that it would go through a comprehensive investigation
of Colbert’s remarks,[37] the result of which was no action taken against
Colbert or _The Late Show_ , reasoning in a public statement released on May
23 that there was "nothing actionable under the FCC’s rules" as the offending
statement had been [properly censored](/wiki/Bleep_censor "Bleep
censor").[38][39]

##
Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Ratings and
viewership[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Ratings and viewership")]

_The Late Show_ debuted to 6.55 million viewers according to [Nielsen Media
Research](/wiki/Nielsen_Media_Research "Nielsen Media Research"), beating out
all late-night competition and averaging a 4.9 rating among metered market
households. With Live+7, the series debut garnered 8.26 million viewers.[40]
The show's ratings quickly dropped to second place behind _[The Tonight Show
Starring Jimmy Fallon](/wiki/The_Tonight_Show_Starring_Jimmy_Fallon "The
Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon")_ but remained ahead of _[Jimmy Kimmel
Live](/wiki/Jimmy_Kimmel_Live "Jimmy Kimmel Live")_.[41] While Colbert still
managed more young viewers than Letterman in his first few months, analyst
[Bill Carter](/wiki/Bill_Carter "Bill Carter") wrote that his "opening splash
seemed to dry faster than expected." He suggested this was due to little
social media presence (where his competitor, Fallon, surged).[42] A study from
_The Hollywood Reporter_ revealed Colbert's version of _The Late Show_ draws
the most heavily [Democratic](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\)
"Democratic Party \(United States\)") audience of the three hour-long late-
night shows in its time slot;[43] Carter noted that "some speculate
[Republican](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)") viewers have tuned Colbert out."[42] An estimated 17% of
Colbert's audience identifies as Republican, according to a survey in late
2015. His audience also has the highest percentage of Democratic viewers
compared to Fallon and Kimmel.

The show's post-[Super Bowl 50](/wiki/Super_Bowl_50 "Super Bowl 50") episode
in 2016 achieved the highest-ever ratings for the _Late Show_ franchise,
attracting an average of 21.1 million viewers.[29] By early 2016, Colbert had
trailed Jimmy Fallon in ratings, with an average 2.90 million viewers and a
.65 rating among adults 18-49.[19] Colbert's first week of live episodes in
July 2016 during the [Republican National
Convention](/wiki/2016_Republican_National_Convention "2016 Republican
National Convention") saw its highest average weekly viewership since May 6,
2016, and a 600% increase in online traffic to clips of the program on CBS
websites.[44][45]

Following the [inauguration](/wiki/Inauguration_of_Donald_Trump "Inauguration
of Donald Trump") of [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") as
president in January 2017, _The Late Show_ began to see major ratings gains,
aided by the program's satire of the Trump administration. In the first full
week after the inauguration, Colbert narrowly beat Fallon for the first time
in average viewership since its premiere.[46] By the end of April, _The Late
Show_ had been the top U.S. late-night program in terms of total viewership
for sixteen consecutive weeks[47] and was rated the number one late night show
by viewership for the first quarter of 2017.[48] _The Late Show_ became the
highest rated late night talk show for the September 2016 to May 2017 season,
averaging more than 3.2 million nightly viewers.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Reviews[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Reviews")]

_The Late Show with Stephen Colbert_ has garnered mostly positive reviews.[49]
_[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_ 's Brian Moylan praised
the show's humor: "This opener was by no means a perfect show, but there were
enough really inventive jokes to make Colbert already seem like an
innovator."[50] Robert Lloyd of _[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times
"Los Angeles Times")_ deemed it a "strong start,"[51] while
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_ 's Brian Lowry
felt it a "mostly terrific" debut, commenting, "Colbert looks like he has the
skill set to settle in and make this job his own, night in and night out."[52]
Many critics considered the show's more political segments as reminiscent of
_[The Colbert Report](/wiki/The_Colbert_Report "The Colbert Report")_.[51][53]
An early interview with [Vice
President](/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States "Vice President of the
United States") [Joe Biden](/wiki/Joe_Biden "Joe Biden") also received praise:
Robert Rorke of the _[New York Post](/wiki/New_York_Post "New York Post")_
commented that the review gave Biden "that essential sense of humanity that
makes people believe in a candidate."[54]

The show's post-[Super Bowl](/wiki/Super_Bowl_50 "Super Bowl 50") episode in
2016 proved polarizing. "Sunday’s live episode felt mostly like a wasted
opportunity – one that probably won’t win many converts among those football
fans sober enough to stick around," said Brian Lowry at
_[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_.[55] Daniel
D'Addario of _[Time](/wiki/Time_\(magazine\) "Time \(magazine\)")_ dubbed his
performance "stiff and uncomfortable," writing, "Colbert might have been
better advised not to bother trying with football at all and just put forward
a program of pure entertainment."[56]

_The Late Show_ has received positive reviews following the inauguration of
[Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") as president. "Colbert may
not be the sarcastic, irony-laden character he once played for Comedy Central,
but as Trump has dominated the news every day since taking office, _The Late
Show_ has become the home for reasoned, but incisive, discussion, on the
perceived overreaches of the White House," said David Sims of _[The
Atlantic](/wiki/The_Atlantic "The Atlantic")_.[57] [James
Poniewozik](/wiki/James_Poniewozik "James Poniewozik") of _[The New York
Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ commented, "Mr.
Colbert’s comedy hasn’t become radically different, but it has been more frank
and caustic...The network-TV Mr. Colbert is more cheery than his cable
character. But it’s as if the Trump administration had solved the problem of
reconciling his new comedy with his old by making truthiness America’s
official language."[58]

##
Broadcast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=The_Late_Show_with_Stephen_Colbert&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Broadcast")]

In Canada, _The Late Show with Stephen Colbert_ airs on
[Global](/wiki/Global_Television_Network "Global Television Network"), airing
in simulcast with CBS in most regions.[59][60]

In Australia, _The Late Show with Stephen Colbert_ airs on
[Ten](/wiki/Network_Ten "Network Ten"), followed by _[The Late Late Show with
James Corden](/wiki/The_Late_Late_Show_with_James_Corden "The Late Late Show
with James Corden")_.[61]

In Asia, _The Late Show with Stephen Colbert_ airs on [RTL CBS
Entertainment](/wiki/RTL_CBS_Entertainment "RTL CBS Entertainment") weeknights
at 10:50PM ([UTC+08:00](/wiki/UTC%2B08:00 "UTC+08:00")) starting September 10,
2015, preceding _[The Late Late Show with James
Corden](/wiki/The_Late_Late_Show_with_James_Corden "The Late Late Show with
James Corden")_.[62]

In [India](/wiki/India "India") and [Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka"),
_The Late Show with Stephen Colbert_ airs on [STAR World
Premiere](/wiki/STAR_World_Premiere "STAR World Premiere") HD.[63]

In [Portugal](/wiki/Portugal "Portugal"), _The Late Show with Stephen Colbert_
airs on [SIC Radical](/wiki/SIC_Radical "SIC Radical").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand"), it airs on free to air
[Prime](/wiki/Prime_\(New_Zealand\) "Prime \(New Zealand\)") at late night
times.[64]
